abstract.text: Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: AppKit Release Notes for macOS Monterey 12

inlineContent.text: AppKit in macOS Monterey 12 includes new features, as well as API changes and deprecations.
Buttons no longer highlight using the accent color when clicked. Before using any subclass that performs custom drawing, inspect the button cell’s
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/appkit/nscell/1526141-interiorbackgroundstyle
property to determine if the bezel draws in a normal or emphasized state.
Buttons now support custom tinting with the
property. This property — previously applied only in the Touch Bar — now functions for all in-window buttons using the
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/appkit/nsbuttontype/nsbuttontypemomentarypushin
style.
When clicking on the track, for linear sliders, circular sliders, or dial, the slider now animates to the new value.
You can now tint sliders with colorful track fills using the
property. This property now functions for all in-window sliders.
Segmented controls now support custom tinting via the
property. This property now functions for all in-window segmented control styles that draw colorful selected segments.
has a new animation when appearing and dismissing.

SF Symbols now support layered symbol images. Layered symbol images use an updated data format to annotate each path element of the symbol with a level in a hierarchy: primary, secondary, tertiary, and so on. At draw time, AppKit can assign different colors to each layer of the symbol using new APIs on
. Many system-provided symbol images redesigned to include layered versions.
now supports merging two configurations with
method.
now includes a read-only property,

, for its current symbol configuration. You can use this property to configure other symbol images to match a reference image, or to merge an image’s existing configuration with a set of new configuration options.
To enable secure coding for a restorable state, implement
. When opted in:
The system requires classes passed to
to explicitly conform to
Set
to
and the
to
for any coder the following implementations or overrides use
set to
Additionally,
must only point at
-compliant values and you need to implement
to specify the type of the object.

The new user preference “Automatically hide and show the menu bar in full screen” in Dock & Menu Bar preferences is enabled by default. In macOS Monterey 12, the user can choose to disable this setting to always show the menu bar in full screen spaces. Standard full screen windows are resized to fit below the menu bar. Some apps assume a full screen-sized window, and don’t work well with this setting.
20-point spacing precedes each group row to make the separation between sections more visible. Source lists have a similar, but smaller, 13-point spacing. This applies to the
and
effective styles in apps linked against the macOS 12 SDK.
doesn’t display the spacing.
The floating group row transition — previously a push transition — instantly replaces the new floating group row. It occurs when the
of the group row’s label meets the bottom of a currently floating group row.
The disclosure button now aligns with the cell view’s
. The system overrides it in
so it matches the baseline of its
(assuming
sets the baseline). Overriding the property and returning
reverts to the previous behavior.
When collapsing several items, the
only posts once. Previously, it posted once per collapsed item.
Setting
to
automatically disabled files, but all of the directory contents were sent to
or
. In macOS Monterey 12, files aren’t sent to the delegate methods unless
is
. In addition, file packages are excluded unless
is
. This change allows optimization in the delegate method.
TextKit 2 introduces a new text layout engine and its associated API. You can use TextKit 2  alongside the existing
API.
and
are the two main controller objects superseding
and
respectively.
managed by
represents a paragraph of text.
stores the layout information in its model objects:
and
In TextKit 2,
encapsulates information associated with a text selection while
manipulates and converts the selection object based on keyboard and mouse navigation actions.

abstract.text: Invoked to request that a window be restored.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates if the app supports secure state restoration.
The color of the button’s bezel, in appearances that support it.
Returns the classes that support secure coding.
Saves the interface-related state of the document.
Saves the interface-related state of the document.
Returns an array of key paths that represent the restorable attributes of the document.
Restores the interface-related state of the document.
Restores a window that was associated with a document, after that document is reopened.
A high-level interface for manipulating image data.
An object that contains the specific font, style, and weight attributes to apply to a symbol image.
An object that coordinates the layout and display of text characters.
A Boolean that indicates whether the user can choose files in the panel.
Asks the delegate whether the specified URL should be enabled in the Open panel.
Posted after the outline view’s selection changes.
A means to display additional content related to existing content on the screen.
Saves the interface-related state of the responder.
Saves the interface-related state of the responder to a keyed archiver either synchronously or asynchronously on the given operation queue.
Restores the interface-related state of the responder.
The color of the selected segment’s bezel, in appearances that support it.
The color of the filled portion of the slider track, in appearances that support it.
A reusable container view shown for a particular cell in a table view that uses rows for content.
Text displayed by the cell.
The table view style resolves to a full-width style.
The table view style resolves to an inset style.
The table view style resolves to a plain style.
The fundamental storage mechanism of TextKit that contains the text managed by the system.
The distance (in points) between the top of the view’s alignment rectangle and its topmost baseline.
The restoration class associated with the window.
A set of methods that restoration classes must implement to handle the recreation of windows.
Asks the class to provide a new window for the specified identifier.
Manage text storage and perform custom layout of text-based content in your app’s views.
A concrete object for managing your view’s text content and generating the text elements necessary for layout.
A class that represents the layout fragment typically corresponding to a rendering surface, such as a layer or view subclass.
The primary class that you use to manage text layout and presentation for custom text displays.
A class that represents a line fragment as a single textual layout and rendering unit inside a text layout fragment.
A class that represents a single paragraph backed by an attributed string as the contents.
A class that represents a single logical selection context that corresponds to an insertion point.
An interface you use to expose methods for obtaining results from actions performed on text selections.
Returns a configuration object that applies the specified configuration values on top of the current object’s values.
Indicates whether the archiver requires all archived classes to resist object substitution attacks.
The action the coder should take when decoding fails.
A failure policy that directs the coder to capture the failure as an error object.
Gives the delegate the opportunity to filter items that it doesn’t want the user to choose.
Learn about changes to the macOS SDK.
